qas.question: What was the amount of participation by women in religious observances?
What religious act did women not perform?
What priesthood was reserved solely for women?
With what are many deities aligned for women in Rome's religions?

context: Roman women were present at most festivals and cult observances. Some rituals specifically required the presence of women, but their active participation was <a0_0>limited<a0_0/>. As a rule women did not perform <a1_0>animal sacrifice<a1_0/>, the central rite of most major public ceremonies. In addition to the public priesthood of the <a2_0>Vestals<a2_0/>, some cult practices were reserved for women only. The rites of the <a3_0>Bona Dea<a3_0/> excluded men entirely. Because women enter the public record less frequently than men, their religious practices are less known, and even family cults were headed by the paterfamilias. A host of deities, however, are associated with <a4_0>motherhood<a4_0/>. Juno, Diana, Lucina, and specialized divine attendants presided over the life-threatening act of giving birth and the perils of caring for a baby at a time when the infant mortality rate was as high as 40 percent.
